etymology.description: 水(水) (shuǐ, "water") + 少(少) (shǎo, "to lack; to be short of") = water with few particles -> sand
etymology.interpretation: The character 沙(shā, "sand") represents the presence of sparse particles (sand) in water, suggesting how sand is often found in conjunction with water, like along riverbanks.

parts.english: to lack; to be short of

examples.chinese: 海滩上的沙很细(海灘上的沙很細)。
examples.pinyin: Hǎi tān shàng de shā hěn xì.
examples.english: The sand on the beach is very fine.

examples.chinese: 孩子们带着桶和铲子(孩子們帶著桶和鏟子)，在沙滩上建城堡(在沙灘上建城堡)。
examples.pinyin: Háizimen dài zhe tǒng hé chǎnzi, zài shā tān shàng jiàn chéngbǎo.
examples.english: The children carry buckets and shovels, building castles on the beach.

examples.chinese: 风吹起沙尘(風吹起沙塵)，让人有点不适(讓人有點不適)。
examples.pinyin: Fēng chuī qǐ shāchén, ràng rén yǒudiǎn bùshì.
examples.english: The wind kicks up sand dust, making people feel a bit uncomfortable.
